Authors:
Yi Yang, Shinichiro Maruyama, Hiroyuki Sekimoto, Hidetoshi
Sakayama, Hisayoshi Nozaki
Title:
An extended phylogenetic analysis reveals non-green
phosphoribulokinase genes from two lineages of “green” secondary
photosyntheic eukaryotes: Euglenophyta and Chlorarachniophyta
Keywords:
Horizontal gene transfer  Endosymbiotic gene transfer 
Phosphoribulokinase  Calvin cycle  Endosymbiosis  Chromalveolata 
Chrorarachniophyta  Englenophyta
Abstract:
Background Endosymbiotic gene transfer (EGT) is a common
event following an endosymbiosis, which is responsible for the
establishment of mitochondria and plastids in eukaryotic cells. As a
result of EGT, a set of genes was transferred to the nucleus of the
host. Many genes of Calvin cycle enzymes are considered EGT-derived, and
phosphoribulokinase gene (PRK) may be ideal to trace historical events
of plastid EGT due to its conservative sequences and few evolutionary
replacement from mitochondrial homologues. Although the previous
phylogenetic research on PRK genes demonstrated a chromalveolate- or
red-derived PRK gene from Euglenophyta or Chlorarachniophyta,
respectively, only a single operational taxonomic unit (OTU) (Euglena
and Bigelowiella) was analyzed in each of these two secondary “green”
photosynthetic eukaryotic groups.
